body: Tests pass locally.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
Thanks for the reviews. Addressed the comments. I think we can close the jira for now and open a new one if it ever shows up again.

@wushujames Thanks for the changes. I had some comments, but functionally this is great and fills in a bunch of important missing topic configs. Re: docs changes, feel free to leave them to a later patch (I think the only reason it may have made sense was that I had to go double check that they were, in fact, the same as the existing docs; once I realized that, reviewing that chunk of code wasn't really worthwhile). I think this is a great improvement since nobody wants to maintain this manually, just had a couple of possible refinements.

@wushujames, it's generally a good idea to merge trunk into the branch so that when someone (including yourself) tests your branch, they test the code as it will be once it's merged.

It sounds like Github would do the merge if it can, but of course you're right that it's better for me to see it myself in order to test it. And Github would not be able to resolve merge conflicts, so I should do it myself anyway.

I updated my branch to the latest trunk. I'm not sure if Jenkins is going to auto-rebuild it.

And cherry-picked to 0.10.0 after resolving the conflicts.
Made one more pass.
One question otherwise LGTM.
For whatever reason, the docs bucket `RequestQueueTimeMs` and `ResponseQueueTimeMs` into `QueueTimeMs`. But in actuality, they're separated. Below is a jconsole screen shot from `0.10.0.0`:

Hello @antonnazaruk very helpful feedbacks, thanks!! Let me try to address some of them as well as the `punctuate` function in general.
1. KTable: in fact it is not only designed for small tables, but can be used to host large tables with billions of records as long as it is partitioned on sufficient number of instances (note that each local state store just represent a "shard" of the global store which can be big), and just to give you some references Confluent's Kafka Enterprise Control Center also use Kafka Streams for aggregating and monitoring tracking events and stats, whose topology is complex with a bunch of sub-topologies and large traffic as well. So I feel that your use case would still be best fit with KTable-KTable join in Streams DSL.

Note that there are some improvements we are working on such as non-key KTable-KTable join as well: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Discussion%3A+Non-key+KTable-KTable+Joins
1. KStream aggregations: I think aggregate / reduce also have support for event-time based windowing, such as hopping windows and tumbling windows; it does not support sliding window (i.e. a new window to be created for EACH incoming record), which is only used in joins. If you can point me to which functions you were looking at for which AK version I can help more regarding the windowing function. That said, I still feel your use case would fit better in a non-windowed KTable-KTable join.
2. Event timestamp: actually you can access the current processed record's event time through `ProcessorContext`, which is passed in `init()` call, you can just maintain it locally and access its `ProcessorContext.timestamp()` in `process()`.
3. Finally, for `punctuate` function, I agree with you that there are common cases that system-time based triggering. We could add a config for controlling the mode or add another function in `Processor` just to distinguish these two types of `punctuates`. Let me have some more brain-storm with my team and get back to you soon.

Let me know if you have more thoughts regarding my replies above.

Jenkins claimed that the PR failed in :streams:test, but the log didn't give any indication as to where. `./gradlew :streams:test` worked fine on my dev machine. Closing/reopening PR in order to kick Jenkins.

The template approach looks reasonable to me, and I think it would be a great feature to add, cc @ijuma .

About the stream metrics, since it is still under going some refactoring now we can consider excluding them for this PR, and we can add the same approach for its metrics later after the refactoring is done.

LGTM
LGTM, thanks @cotedm!

@johnhofman Not sure I understand the issue w/ `final` re: map key and value schemas. How does this differ at all from self-referential schemas where the contents of the schema need to be mutable but the reference to the schema object itself doesn't need to be? And `equals` and `hashcode` issues seem like they can be resolved by checking for identity equality to break these loops? Or is the issue that we need to track multiple schemas if schemas aren't directly self-referential but instead are indirectly self-referential?

I'm not quite sure what you mean by the type vs instance of the type, but I think in your terms `parameters` are really about the instance of the type. The simplest example is the `Decimal` logical type -- it has a `scale` parameter that controls the decimal precision. It's tied to the instance of the type since we can have many different schemas of type `Decimal`, but they can differ in precision.

@deragon Have kicked off https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/492 just to check that we don't break anything non-Cygwin. If we can clean up unrelated changes and the system tests look good, I think we can merge this.

Hmm, looking at this (at long last). It seems like this doesn't make it into public API documentation where we would want these refinements? @hachikuji I'd be happy to merge, though I think there are other ongoing patches that will be affected -- is there somewhere in the public API docs we could better add clarification re: semantics?

Thanks for the review @ijuma & @junrao. I have updated the patch.
@mweirauch The instructions say to copy `config/server.properties`, so the value for `zookeeper.connect` should already exist in the file, along with a lot of other settings.

@granthenke I think different people just get used to handling different subsets of sh, and it's often easier to go the more verbose route than make sure you're not using a bashism in a sh script (although we decided at some point that assuming bash is fine as long as we use it in the shebang). For example, it seems like the form you used is valid sh, but the forms `${FOO=default}` and `${FOO:=default}` are bashisms.

@ewencp My concept of `instance` vs `type` (I expect there is correct terminology for this, but I haven't yet come across it) is easily illustrated by comparing an avro schema with it's connect schema equivalent :

```
{"type":"record",
 "name":"avro",
 "fields":[{"name":"int","type":"int"}, 
           {"name":"int_optional","type":["null","int"]},
           {"name":"int_with_default","type":"int","default":"0"}]
}
```

The record `avro` has three fields, all different `instances` of the type int. The three fields all reference the same type, however one instance is optional, one instance has a default value and the other is just a plain int.

As a `ConnectSchema` this would be constructed:

```
SchemaBuilder.struct().name("connect")
  .field("int", Schema.INT32_SCHEMA)
  .field("int_optional", Schema.OPTIONAL_INT32_SCHEMA)
  .field("int_with_default", SchemaBuilder.int32().defaultValue(0).build())
.build();
```

This represents a record with the same fields, except here the "optionality" and "default" are embedded in the schema so that each field actually references a different schema object. This means that we need the `FutureSchema` as a wrapper that can reference an existing schema (to reuse the type defining properties) but can override the `optional` and `default` properties. 

Re: equality and hashing: The tricky part is indeed indirectly cyclic schema's, and making the solution thread-safe. The only solution I can think of is to track the visited nodes and break the cycle when revisiting a node. To do this thread-safe a "context" needs to be passed along with the comparison, the resulting code is in the latest change set.

Maybe it makes sense to fix that here?

@ewencp Forgot to mention that [I had informed](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/kafka-dev/201607.mbox/%3cOFB2534DD4.69FBE5D2-ON00257FFD.005F3FC3-88257FFD.00600D8D@notes.na.collabserv.com%3e) Spark and Storm users about this potential change and except for one did not receive any feedback on those mailing lists. Not sure if we need to do anything further for that.

@becketqin It should still be supported. Can you not see jobs on Confluent's Jenkins at all? It's possible in some other reorganization the name of the job changed, it is now `system-test-kafka-branch-builder`.

In any case, I kicked of a run and some tests do indeed fail: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2016-08-07--001.1470637481--becketqin--KAFKA-3554--ebdcffe/report.html There seem to be at least a couple of reasons (a test against 0.8.2.2 where `KafkaProducer.flush()` doesn't exist and some tests that need a value bound set since they have compression enabled are the first ones I checked, but I haven't scanned through all the failures to get an exhaustive list of issues).

@granthenke I'd probably just leave both as they are for now. There is actually a difference between them -- the `if` version will override variables if they exist but are empty, whereas the version you're using only uses the default for unset variables. So, e.g., if you wanted `EXTRA_ARGS=""`, you'd need to use your version (or know why it is being overridden and add whitespace or something). So probably your version is the right way to handle most args like this, although I'm not sure its worth the effort to proactively clean up the rest of those cases.

Removing the `export` is important though -- you should really only `export` if it should be visible to subprocesses, but in this case its just a local variable.
LGTM except one minor comment. cc @ijuma @gwenshap .
ping @ijuma @enothereska @mjsax
@vahidhashemian I think if we've made a best effort to solicit feedback from them, that's all we can really do.

@hachikuji I think the section on Manual Offset Control can be read as suggesting that if you poll() and get records, then crash, auto commit might cause you to lose those messages. This is basically the case where we used to have buggy code that would allow the auto commit to happen at the end of poll() after the position had been updated. There was an email thread where Jay asked if this was accurate anymore and presumably quoted the exact section of the docs, but I can't find it now so I can't verify if that was the only section that was problematic.

@ewencp Good point. That comment is at least a little misleading. It can be clarified to emphasize that offsets for records returned in a call to poll() will not be committed until a subsequent call to poll(). So as long as you consume all the records returned, then the consumer provides "at least once" guarantees with autocommit enabled.
One minor comment, otherwise LGTM.

@guozhangwang, very detailed and comprehensive answers, thanks a lot. 

I should have better spent my time with API learning to not put those incorrect statements above. I apologize for that. 

Now you made me feel doubts if chosen (so far) approach with HBase is the best for me. ))

However, I still have better feeling for some cases with global-scalable-fast KV store. I realize that global KV store sounds like anti-pattern in streaming world - but it has some benefits with bringing it's own cost. I think that get/put throughput we have with HBase is solid enough comparing to amount of real-time data we consume (and expect to consume in near and long future). And HBase is scaling horizontally, so even unexpected real-time data growth will be handled by adding more nodes to a cluster. And yes, when all use-cases will be moved out from MySQL to new materialized viewes - SQL storage will be simply removed and data will be sent directly to kafka (topic that comes first after CDC data extraction from debezium topics). 

These are my main concerns :

1) Maintenance complexity. We have ~50 databases with the same DDL (shards) and target data occupies ~50 tables (majority of tables have dozens/hundreds of millions of records) in every database (due to data model normalization). So, only with current data model streaming we'll have like 50*50=2500 debezium CDC topics (one topic per table). And we want to simply clone this solution for other data models in future. I can't predict and measure how many topics (partitions) will be needed with Streams DSL approach, but this number is going to be significantly higher. And from operations standpoint the smaller amount of partitions you have - the happier you are (not a general rule, but when number goes beyond couple of thousands it may be true).

2) Deployment/monitoring complexity. With Streams DSL approach we'll end up with 10-15 unique topologies (and some extra ones to prepare data for joins -- I am happy FK-joins are currently in progress by kafka community). With HBase approach there will be just two processor topologies : 
    a) topology that consumes data from debezium topic(s), shrinks it and sends to single topic (with many partitions) under composed key
    b) topology, that consumes data from previous topic and aggregates it using HBase (with "tick" topic) and sends consolidated transaction data to target topic. 

Yes, that's a tradeoff, since join/aggregation logic lies now on our shoulders - consolidate all relevant transaction pieces from HBase. But from other side we have enough flexibility to create generic solution, that will be relatively easily copied to other data models without coding (just processing meta-data specification). 

I am excited to hear your thoughts on that, and many thanks in advance!

LGTM. Merged to trunk.
@dguy Seems the previous PR on null checking has some conflicts with this one, could you rebase?

@granthenke : Thanks for the update. The patch looks good to me. I have just one design question. Looking at the code, I realize that we have Create at Cluster, but Delete at Topic. This seems a bit asymmetric. Would it be more natural to have Delete at Cluster too?

@junrao, are you talking about ACLs? I agree that it's a bit weird. In fact, I had expected Create at Topic too. If you were to change Delete to be at Cluster, it would be a bit weird because you would pass a topic name to the Cluster resource, right?

@ijuma : If Delete is at Cluster, it will work the same way as Create. You can only have a singleton cluster as the resource and the Delete will apply to all topics. In the common case, only the admin can create/delete topics. So having Create/Delete at the cluster level makes sense. Not sure how common it is for a user to be able to delete a single topic and yet is not the admin.

@junrao Thank you for the review. 

You are right its a bit funny and likely pretty verbose. 

I think the initial goal in KIP-11 was to be as fine grained as possible. Create was set at the cluster level since the topic didn't exist yet but delete was likely set at the topic level since now there was a resource to control. 

Alternatively both could be allowed. This would allow it to be set at the cluster or topic level. Though I think you are right that common case would be at the cluster level. 

The problem with hierarchical/inherited ACLs is that the expected behavior isn't specified well today and would be up to the individual Authorizer implementation to authorize correctly. The SimpleAclAuthorizer does this with the [ALL Operation](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/security/auth/SimpleAclAuthorizer.scala#L167)  and the [Read/Write to Describe Operation](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/security/auth/SimpleAclAuthorizer.scala#L130-L134). 

Another option is to support wildcard resources similar to how we support wildcard principles. A topic resource with name \* could grant access to delete any topic.

In the end those are more complicated approaches, when as you said the common case would be at the cluster level. 

The behavior to control delete on the topic resource instead of the cluster was defined in [KIP-11](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-11+-+Authorization+Interface). Is it something we can change now? Would we need a discussion and a vote? 

Whatever is decided I am happy to make a change.

The current usage maps to how I would expect things to work with a REST API -- since the resource doesn't exist yet, Create is targeted at the collection (which for Topics is presumably Cluster). Since Delete is against a specific topic (a specific resource) it is targeted at that specific resource. Not sure about how this maps to auth. Some APIs support both `POST /cluster` and `PUT /cluster/topic` which I suppose lets you specify ACLs at both levels.

It's also a bit weird that creation is at the level of the Cluster instead of some Topics collection. We don't have many resources at the moment so maybe the potential collisions don't matter, but it doesn't seem great that you have to get any Create for a collection would have to enable Create for all types at the Cluster level.

If someone wants an app to only be authorized to create/delete topics associated with that app, it seems like the Topic resource version is necessary, right? Like, if you want to isolate a streams app which might need to reset itself (and therefore delete/recreate topics)?

@ewencp I think this starts to get into [KIP-37 - Add Namespaces to Kafka](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-37+-+Add+Namespaces+to+Kafka). 

I agree its unfortunate that we give Create to the entire scope of the cluster. (As far as Create for all types, this will likely need to be handled if we have a collision with a new Operation or something)

> If someone wants an app to only be authorized to create/delete topics associated with that app

I think providing a detailed set of topics to your admin who in turn gives you create ACLs is pretty cumbersome too. Instead I would suggest the admin gives all privileges to a namespace for that app team. They can then create and delete while being isolated from others. Its likely at the time we introduce namespaces that we would need to define how privileges are handled and inherited.

@granthenke Yeah, they are getting into the same territory. A more complex authorizer could effectively implement namespacing for ACLs without real namespacing in Kafka though, just by supporting regex/wildcards (I haven't followed it carefully, but my understanding was that the simple authorizer we have only supports `*` or a specific resource). But maybe that's really just a hacky workaround for real namespaces.
@rajinisivaram Is this still passing for you? Testing locally it's failing (second producer isn't starting successfully/not getting data). Haven't checked an AWS test yet.

@ewencp I had run the sanity tests and the new hostname verification tests locally yesterday and they had passed. I had also started a full test run of this branch after the rebase to make sure that nothing was broken. That passed too (https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/494/)
@ijuma I'd appreciate it if you could review this. It should be simple enough fix. Thanks.
Do you know under what scenarios `cleaner` can be null?
LGTM, merged to trunk.

It has eluded me, but after reading code from Kafka through OpenJDK's, this is my guess.
If the following call stack happened:
OffsetIndex._entries = 0 //the "0" here triggers the condition for the cleaner to be null
OffsetIndex.truncateToEntries(0)
OffsetIndex.truncate()
LogSegment.recover()

Followed by another call stack say from LogCleaner sometime:
raf.getChannel().map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_WRITE, 0, roundedNewSize) //roundedNewSize=0
OffsetIndex.resize(_entries \* 8) //basically resize(0)
OffsetIndex.trimToValidSize()

Now, when roundedNewSize = 0, the OpenJDK's sun.nio.ch.FileChannelImpl.map() will return "Util.newMappedByteBufferR(0, 0, dummy, null)". Notice that the last param is null. That sets the cleaner inside the map to be null too.

I've made the suggested changes, @ewencp 
Thanks for the feedback! Let me know how it looks now :)

I did the profiling with a slightly modified `SimpleBenchmark` class, with 16 threads on the streams client (and hence 16 partitions for `simpleBenchmarkSourceTopic`), the profiling as long as benchmarking results are attached.

First is from branch KAFKA-3769
![k3769](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10729597/17575982/318bc57c-5f23-11e6-96e8-ca67c7f64027.png)

And then from trunk (have to use to images since the trace was too long)
![trunk-part1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10729597/17575987/4afce770-5f23-11e6-8eb0-3f127ebe4f10.png)

![trunk-part2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10729597/17575990/4eb18510-5f23-11e6-81e7-6d8eb1c97206.png)
1. The benchmark results in terms of throughput is at the bottom of the image, from the IDEA console.
2. There are three groups of 16 threads, each group correspond to one benchmark case: `streams`, `streamsWithSink`, `streamsWithStore`.
3. For the first case there is no IO except fetching, whereas for the second there are some blocking due synchronization on producer buffer to sending to Sink, and for the third there are some blocking for rocksDB IO.
4. We can see that for trunk, even with the first case there are "idle" ratio, and for the other two cases, the "idle" ratio is much higher than KAFKA-2769 case. And the throughput is worse.

@ijuma @gfodor @miguno Please review again. Note that there are a few minor improvements to the `SimpleBenchmark` code while I am doing the profiling, and also added but commented `enable.topic.delete` in `server.properties`.
